review_title: shallow social commentary wrapped in an unfunny SF comedy
review_detailed_main:
When you make an idea-movie, which should also act as a social commentary on the contemporary society, then you must be prepared to put an edge in it. To take chances. To go against mainstream. It's risky, but it pays off if you do it right.

The "Stepford wives" starts on the right note, but soon enough it's apparent that the director Frank Oz chose to play it safe. The final result looks more like something that was scheduled to appear in Marvel comics, but somehow got turned into a new big-budget Nicole Kidman flick.

Just look at the basics of the plot: insecure husbands turn their successful wives into robots. This operation consists of (not actually seen in the movie) removing the brains from the wives, putting them in robot bodies, AND mind-controlling those brains. What I want to know is this - WHY NOT JUST BUILD A ROBOT WIFE AND BE DONE WITH IT?!? Why this whole "brain-removing" part? Yes, yes, I know, it's a - *wink* *wink* - social commentary. Yeah, right. So is Tomb Raider.

To sum up in one sentence - if you put the gaping plot holes and ridiculous storyline aside, what you get is a light comedy with a moderately good cast, a few little laughs and a horrible please-the-audience ending.

To be sincere, this movie left a bad taste in my mouth. I expected it to be much more intelligent. After the showing I felt like somebody suckered me into seeing a Pokemon movie. If I had to rate this flick, I'd give it 4 out of 10, but only because the average quality of recent Hollywood movies is so bad it wouldn't be fair to go any lower.

Don't rent this. Watch it on TV, and only if nothing else is on.

review_title: I had some great laughs, and some yawns too...
review_detailed_main:
Nicole Kidman is a talented actress but this kind of movie isn't her bag. Broderick, who is comic talent, was not given an ample opportunity to be funny based on the script. However, Bette Midler and Roger Bart were funny beyond words. They stole the show! This movie would have failed without them. It was really magic watching them add levity to the film's semi-dark atmosphere.

Faith Hill is added as merely a "prop" in the background so I was unable to judge her performance. Once again Bart and Bette were the real ones to watch her. Wait until it comes on DVD, save your theater money for other films.

Take two things into account with this review.

#1- The Stepford Wives movie from 1975 is one of my favourite movies.

#2- I completely understood that this remake was going to be something different.

In fact, I was so accepting of the fact that Frank Oz chose to make this a satirical comedy, that I was actually looking forward to the many changes and updates that this remake was going to have. Even walking out of the theatre, I was judging this very much as it's own movie. Having said that, I have to say that I don't completely dislike this movie, I just felt very let down, not just as a fan of The Stepford Wives, but as a normal filmgoer as well. There are a lot of good things offered in this remake. The cast is outstanding. I disagree with many who think Matthew Broderick was underused. I thought he was perfectly used, and I liked that they made his character more sympathetic. In a way, you have more respect for him than you do Joanna, unlike the original. And also unlike the original, Joanna is very sleezy, and overall a horrible human being with some redeemable qualities. Being a straight male, I almost feel weird saying this, but Bette Midler was perhaps the best thing about the movie. She put an interesting spin on the character of Bobbie. Most of the jokes are clever, and for the most part classy.

But here is the major problem. Frank Oz made the horrible mistake of updating this movie and changing a lot of the story, just for the sake of changing it. I have a feeling that he wanted to do something different to make this his own movie, but never thought about it hard enough to make it different in a clever way. The climax plays out just like the original, and has the supermarket scene with the Stepford Wives, but then there's a whole "second ending" that not only seems like a sloppy and thoughtless twist, but it makes very little sense. This is the same mistake that Planet Of The Apes and Rollerball both made with their remakes. They tried to surprise the audience with a new shocking twist, but it's not thought out or well executed, and it's just plain dumb. Then my other big complaint is the pacing of the movie. There's far too much "filler" in the middle section. Scenes that draw out the inevitable un-necessarily. Then when it finally comes time for the real excitement in the climax, they rush through it. I was very pleased how Oz filmed and pieced together the climax. Even the way the confrontation at the mansion was changed up, I was impressed. But what was the sense of condensing the best part of the movie into a few rushed minutes when there were several scenes in the middle section that were tediously dull? Ultimately, it's the various new twists and cheap modern day updates that bury this movie. It's not at all that I objected to the changes as a fan of the original, it's because they don't fit the basic theme and tone of the rest of the movie. So many of these modern day changes (just for the sake of changing) feel wildly out of place.

There is a lot of good material and great scenes, and for the most part the story is told well. I think when this comes out on video and DVD I'm going to put this on tape, minus some of the scenes from the middle, and minus the second ending. I'm hoping I'll enjoy it a lot more that way. One more thing. Why did they change the knife scene????? A hand on a stove element? Lame substitution.

review_title: To Silly to Be Dark, To Dark To Be Silly
review_detailed_main:
For the record, I never saw the original.

Plot: .6/2: Joanna Eberhart (Kidman) has had a nervous breakdown. She was a major TV executive until one of the participants on her show (White) gets screwed over and loses his wife in the game and tries to kill both his wife and Joanna. This gets Joanna fired. So her husband Walter Fresby (Broderick) quits his job and gets his family to move to Stepford, a town in Connecticut, to get away from it all. When they arrive, Joanna realizes this place is nothing normal. The whole town is full of women who are apparently perfect. They all have blond hair, do all the housework and have screaming orgasms. All the men go away to the Men's Club on a regular schedule, where they have a meeting hosted by Mike Wellington (Walken), apparently the town leader. Joanna, along with Jewish novelist Bobbie Markowitz (Midler) and flamboyant homosexual Roger Bannister (Bart), apparently the only other normal wives (or in Roger's case, bitches), sets out to figure out what the secret is behind Stepford's closed doors.

If you don't know what is wrong with them, you have been hiding in a hole since the '70s. Since everyone knows what the Stepford wives are, there is no shock factor involved in this movie. They told you in the goddamn trailer what was happening. Since it is a remake, none of the plot is surprising, besides one slight twist that might not be completely what Stepford newbies may expect. The problem is that there are about 50 plot holes all over the place. Are the women robots or have they been programmed. It obviously says they are programmed, but there are many instances where it clearly shows them as robots. The ending makes absolutely no sense whatsoever. In fact, most of the movie is nonsensical. If this were an original, I'd be lenient. This is, however, a remake, so I would expect them to build on the original, not make it crappier.

Comedy: .7/2: Any comedy in this movie is just a zinger here or there. Granted, those are some good zingers ("I worked at AOL" "Is that why the women are so slow?"), but it rarely ventures outside of that. There are some easy gay jokes involving Roger, some funny Jewish jokes involving Bobbie and a great cameo by Mike White, but it's not enough, and they could have spent much more time making fun of the Stepfordians while instead they tried run of the mill jokes.

Suspense: .3/2: Since it is a remake of a movie that coined an almost Dictionary worthy term, there is little suspense left available, probably the reason they went for the comedy angle. They do squeeze a little bit of suspense here and there, but most of it is just too silly to take seriously.

Acting: 1.3/2: Oh, the acting is average. Kidman (Eyes Wide Shut) is OK, Broderick (Ferris Bueller's Day Off) is mediocre, Midler (Get Shorty) is good, Bart (the upcoming The Producers) is stereotypical but good, Close (Air Force One) and Walken (The Rundown) are good, but wasted, Lovitz (SNL) is a great choice, but wasted and Mike White is great in his short role. It could have been worse.

Entertainment: .5/2: For all the crappy plot, all the crappy zingers and all the crappy suspense, The Stepford Wives could have been worse. It needed to be a lot better, however. It's too silly to take seriously, to dark to be funny.

Total: 44%: As I said above, The Stepford Wives is too silly to be suspenseful and too dark to be silly. It has one of the biggest plot holes in recent memories. It could have been good, but it just didn't try hard enough. It was directed by Yoda. That's pretty funny.

Despite an A-list cast, this is a really poor and disjointed film that is much more about the stars than it is about any cohesive story. Television executive "Joanna" (Nicole Kidman) has burned the candle at both ends for too long, has a bit of a breakdown, and is shunted off to the manicured hedges and lawns of Stepford in Connecticut by her rather insipid husband "Walter" (Matthew Broderick). It doesn't take them long to realise that this is conceivably the most sterile, charm free place on the planet. All their neighbours have wives who would vie for the most vacuous woman prize - doting on their looks, their dresses, their hair, their gardens - whilst their men folk, under the watchful eye of "Mike Wellington" (Christopher Walker) and his uber-glamorous wife "Claire" (Glenn Close) seem to live the life of Reilly. Luckily, "Bobbie" (Bette Midler) offers "Joanna" the vaguest of lifelines as the only other voice of near sanity in this oasis of feminine perfection, but how long before they succumb too - or can they resist the mysterious effects of the spa and the gentleman's club? There is really very little to like or enjoy in this. For it to have worked, it would have required much more humour and charisma on screen. The narrative meanders in just too flat and stolid a fashion, with little for us to get our teeth into. Middler has probably the best chance at injecting a degree of personality into the thing, but even she struggles with the wordy dialogue and the lacklustre delivery. It looks good, effort has certainly been expended there - but the rest of this is just poor and disappointing. The 1975 film isn't great, but it's way better than this.

review_title: Outstanding in most respects, and entertaining above all.
review_detailed_main:
The problem with this film is that it could have been an absolute masterpiece... if they'd managed to figure out how they wanted to do the robot/brainwashed women. If you're paying attention during the film you'll eventually realize that the filmmakers obviously couldn't decide whether or not to go with robots, or with some sort of nano-tech engineered chips being implanted in the womens brains. My guess is that the nano-tech chips were what they decided on after shooting too many scenes with robot oriented material. My wife has decided that the fact that they couldn't make it one way or the other gives this film a D grade, but I tend to like it more than that. If they would've just gone with the nano-tech chips from the beginning the film would've been spectacular! The mood, set design, acting, and dialogue were very entertaining... thrilling, comedic...very engrossing. But at the end of the day you're still left bothered by the obvious fact that they reshot some material, but used other material and so it comes off as a film that isn't pure. I suppose it feels a bit insulting to the intelligence - did they not realize that the public would catch that glaring mistake? It just makes me sick to my stomach when I see something like this happen to a film that could've been amazing. Shame on whomever didn't approve enough budget to rewrite and reshoot EvERYTHING that needed to be fixed (to make it either all robot material, or all nano-chipped material). It's your fault the film has languished at the box office. In the future, remember that the public will catch you EVERY time you try to get away with less than 100%.

In closing, if you're in the mood for an imperfect but entertaining film then this one should fill the bill nicely.

This remake of the Stepford Wives, didn't do enough to capitalise on the great story within. A fine cast of Bette Midler, Nicole Kidman, Glenn Close, Christopher Walken, I don't include Broderick in this list (he should come with a 'I make bad Movies' badge attached) Now i have not seen the original, but i liked the idea and was interested by the trailer, only to find that the movie feel very flat in the first 10 minutes or so, and just failed to recover.

Good Ideas and Cast don't always make good films, you have been warned.

4/10

review_title: laughed hard, as did a very full theater!
review_detailed_main:
Despite "iffy" reviews, a friend and I could not wait to see this remake. We went Friday afternoon and the theater was full. During the movie, there was lots of loud laughter throughout the theater. The audience clearly enjoyed this movie, as did we.

In fact, this movie is a hoot. From start to finish it is a side-splitting, over the top, tongue-in-cheek revision of the original film. Although (as has been noted in other comments) the ending is a "little" disconnected from the earlier explanations of the Stepfordization process, it was not until I had gotten home that I even realized this.

It is precisely because the remake is so over done, the circumstances so outrageous, that the present-day setting provides such a perfect comedic set-up for this introduction to the town of Stepford. In the beginning, Kidman's T.V. executive persona is seen presenting a Fall line-up of reality T.V. shows that mimics Survivor and its progeny, but also introduces the battle of the sexes that is taken to the extreme in the town of Stepford. By the time of her sudden departure from the network and her family's move to the suburbs, I was already in fits of laughter (as were those around me) and looking forward to the introduction of Bette Midler and Glenn Close's characters. I was not disappointed.

Bette Midler's droll commentary on her too-perfect neighbors, and the friendship between Bette Midler's Bobbi, Nicole Kidman's Joanna, and their Gay neighbor, provides the context for some of the absolutely funniest movie moments I have seen this year. As with many absolutely hysterical movies, if one examines the plot too closely deep holes can be discovered. The beauty of this film is that while in the theatre, you are kept laughing too hard to give much thought to anything other than catching your breath before the next joke is upon you.

When I first heard they were going to remake the 1975 classic, I thought it'd be interesting: Nicole Kidman and Matthew Broderick had the leads, and Glenn Close I assumed would play the level-headed psychologist portrayed by Carol Rossen in the original who tries to help Katharine Ross. Then I heard it was going to be a comedy and Glenn Close had another eccentric role unworthy of her talents. The film is mercifully about 20 minutes shorter (script issues?) than the original and the last 20 minutes are ludicrous. It appears there may have been tampering with the editing after the first test-showing, causing inane plot developments. If the women are indeed human (with electrodes in their brains) how can a character spout ATM bills? How can the Midler character not feel the stove flame burning her hand? In a final confrontation, Kidman stands by her robotic replica as they descend to the dungeon (but the women were supposed to be real with electrodes in them)! In the last scene poor Close is actually cuddling a HEAD. The story stands much better as a horror-mystery thriller so see the original Ross, Paul Prentiss classic. While leisurely, it builds to an unforgettable final sequence.

review_title: Easily The Worst And Most Unnecessary Remake Ever!
Watch the original first, then enjoy this version...

review_detailed_main:
Word was leaked early that this film was a disaster. Test screenings went miserably and the ending had to be re-filmed. It sat on the shelves for close to a year. Nicole Kidman said nasty things about director Frank Oz behind his back, and the cast and crew in turn said things about her. Matthew Broderick said it was one of his worst filming experiences of his career.

And then the movie came out and flopped. It deserved to. It's a huge mess - an uninspired, silly, over-the-top, stupid, insulting, smug, self-conscious little "comedy" that is too nice to be dark and too dark to be nice.

The first half is pretty clever and I found it amusing. Nicole Kidman has a nervous breakdown and moves out of the city with her husband (Broderick) to get away from the chaos. Once there they find a home in a small community named Stepford, begun by a local millionaire (Christopher Walken).

She makes some friends with neighbors Jon Lovitz and Bette Midler, but soon realizes the local "perfect wives" are indeed just that - and may in fact be robots.

The movie tries to be a satire of our repression of women's rights and so on and so forth. It tries to criticize the lustful sexual appetite of men and say that women are more than just bodies. They have souls and feelings and emotions.

But this is a simple point and even by today's standards it's outdated itself - this was far more prescient back in the '50s and '60s when the original took place. Nowadays it seems redundant and smug.

The ending is where it all falls apart - it was obviously reshot to be "happier" and you can even tell because Nicole Kidman's hair is completely different at the end of the movie, which implies she was brought back months later for the re-shoot.

It's a horrible little film that is instantly forgettable and annoying.

To say that there's not a lot to this film is a bit of an understatement. The filmmakers have taken Ira Levin's fairly unsettling original novel and made a conscious decision to make a pretty light-hearted, comedic version. There's nothing wrong with this in theory but the problem is that they seem to have overstepped the mark on this score and have delivered a movie so insubstantial and lacking in tension/darkness that it's highly unlikely to linger at all in your mind after seeing it and little wonder that audiences and critics were severely underwhelmed at the time of the film's release. The starry cast all perform well enough with Roger Bart in particular delivering an engaging comic turn as one of Stepford's gay couple (a feature which, unsurprisingly, did not feature in the novel or the first film version but which actually works quite well here) but the actors are really taking part in something here which is beneath them. That said, the film is never less than watchable and it certainly looks good throughout. The problem is, it's ultimately a rather silly and forgettable affair which, for a big budget, big studio summer event movie, is disappointing to say the least.

It's certainly a premise that's relevant for today's audiences, maybe even more so than when the original "Stepford Wives" was released in 1975, but director Frank Oz and scripter Paul Rudnick transform Ira Levin's allegorical tale of male chauvanism into a hit-or-miss screwball comedy. The film lacks any of the mystery (one of the two key twists is revealed early on), suspense, or horror of the original (which, while a flawed film, at least had some convictions), though many of the scenes are lovingly reproduced (the concluding grocery store sequence, por ejemplo). Nicole Kidman fits well as the lead, a cold-hearted woman looking to jump-start her life, possessing the right blend of sex appeal and comic timing; Bette Midler steals the show as the only other non-conformed female in Stepford. But despite the faithfulness to the original film (transposed somewhat uncomfortably into the realm of comedy), the ending is a shameless cop-out of politically-correct silliness, defying the downbeat sense of total male domination over the female gender which gave the original an eerie resonance--the climax plays it far too safe, and ultimately ruins any modern-day prophecy this film would have been looking to convey (if at all).

THE STEPFORD WIVES is Frank Oz' radical re-thinking of the 1975 classic about the mysterious town of Stepford where everything is not as neat and clean as it appears on the outside. In the original, Katherine Ross and Paula Prentiss played two relatively new citizens of Stepford, who desperately tried to figure out what was going on with the women of Stepford before falling under the "spell." I found Kidman's performance to be broad and affected, somewhat like a Stepford wife before she is Stepford-ized. The ending here is beyond redemption, but otherwise this remake of the 1975 film from the novel by Ira Levin is not (entirely) bad. It's a different sort of film than the original and probably would amuse (if not offend) Ira Levin if he were alive today. But to put it bluntly, the film is a sellout to politically correct mentalities and could quite easily be called "Revenge of the Stepford Wives." (Actually there was a TV movie from 1980 by that name that I haven't seen.) The original Stepford Wives starred Katharine Ross and Paula Prentiss and was a dark science fiction satire with only a few chuckles and a decidedly dark ending. This film is played mostly for laughs and is full of all sorts of silly (shall I say stupid?) updates, like having a gay couple instead of a black couple and making the wives (prior to their coming to Stepford) very accomplished--CEOs, scientists, etc., while the husbands are Neanderthal nerds. Nicole Kidman's Joanna Eberhart was a top TV exec while her husband Walter Kresby (played sheepishly by Matthew Broderick--note that Joanna did not take his last name) is a kind of ordinary joe and caddy to his wife.

But what about the premise? Let's be honest guys. Wouldn't it be wonderful if our wives were totally devoted to our comfort and pleasure? If they obeyed us and always kept the house and themselves spotless and catered to our every whim? If they didn't get moody and were always rational, etc.? Isn't it the natural state of the human male to be king of his castle and to have dominion over all he surveys? Well, at any rate here's an update on the Stepford Wives for the new millennium, an expansion of the concept, if you will. Every man has not only a totally devoted and loving wife, but a totally devoted and loving mistress (or two). They would be robots of course, manufactured as consumer goods by General Electric, Microsoft and Intel. But here is the zinger: every woman would have a slavishly devoted husband and secret lover, etc. And while we are at it, they would have loving, appreciative and accomplished robotic children. In other words, nobody would actually interact with other living, breathing human beings. How crude, how disgusting. Instead all humans would interact only with perfect robots perfectly designed to make their world a heaven on earth.

Or, more likely we would just be hooked up to an elaborate software program with an utterly convincing virtual reality in which we would have a loyal and loving spouse, two extracurricular lovers..., etc.

Fly in the ointment? I think it would be called boredom.

Bottom line on this film: a few laughs, a good cast wasted, but a nice documentation of filmland executive stupidity.

The film opens brightly with a neat credits sequence and an amusing riff on reality TV as hard-hearted TV executive Joanna Eberhart (Nicole Kidman, looking very plain and unglamorous throughout) unveils her station's programmes for the new season. Sacked by her network when a contestant from one of her shows kills his ex-wife as a result of being on the show, Eberhart moves with her husband (Matthew Broderick) to the wealthy town of Stepford, where she slowly discovers that things are not as they should be.

Nearly all the laughs in this film are contained in the first fifteen minutes (apart from a great AOL dig near the end), but things become increasingly silly once the action moves to Stepford where all the hot wives wear plastic smiles and occasionally move in perfect synchronicity. It's the lazy male's fantasy made real, and there should be a rich vein of humour for writer Paul Rudnick to mine, but unfortunately his script is flat and uninteresting, and modern day sensibilities simply insists that one of the eventual wives is a gay man (Roger Bannister). Once Stepford's wicked secret starts coming to light, the script plays like a 'serious' horror film without all the horror bits taken out as it abandons its increasingly woeful attempts at humour for an ill-conceived mystery that completely fails to involve the viewer.

For a smart, hotshot executive, Eberhart is incredibly slow to fathom out what is going on  in fact she's so slow she has to be told  and the promotional film of the town's leader, Mike (Christopher Walken), while an amusing riff on 50s promo films, actually flies in the face of all we have seen before. The Stepford wives aren't robots at all  even though they double as mobile ATM machines  but real women who have had chips inserted in their heads after "first, we locate the brain." Ah well, the film has lost all audience goodwill by then, anyway, so it doesn't really matter.

I am really astonished by the bad reviews and grades that this film received from many of the IMDb viewers. The film uses the plot in Ira Levin's book and in the older film as a pretext for a more deep and critical view of life in America. I liked it, and I believe that it is one of the best satiric films of the year, more serious and deep than it seems, saying a lot about the rush for kitsch, the politics, the false morality, and the standardized 'model' life as that is so common in the American society today.

It's certainly not a masterpiece, and the lines of the plot are too much simplified and too obvious sometimes. But after all, this is the case with good classic comedy in the tradition of Chaplin. What remained for me are the memorable characters played by Bette Milder, Glenn Close, Walken, and of course, Nicole Kidman. What a great actress! Just watch her in the 20 seconds first plan screen shot when she is told that she is fired from her position as TV anchor. Real anthology stuff.

Yes, this film will not get Oscars this year, and was not well received. Is this because the conservative atmosphere in the US today? Maybe. However, time will make justice to it - I am sure and people will get back to it and love it. It may become a cult movie, but for different reasons than the original 'Stepford Wives'. Right now I gave it 8 out of 10 on my personal scale.

review_title: Why Couldn't It Have Just Taken Itself Seriously?!
Definitely not worth the price of a video rental

review_detailed_main: This movie was torture to sit through. I'm a huge fan of the original Ira Levin novel and the movie, which was a masterpiece. This remake has absolutely no relation to the book, which was a foreboding and suspenseful chiller. Instead, they decided to remake it was an abhorrent comedy. AVOID!!

review_title: One of the worst movies I've ever seen...
review_detailed_main:
There have only been a handful of movies I have ever seen that I wanted to walk out on or stop. This was one of them. The inconsistencies were those that even Hollywoodland can't even get away with. The script was terrible. It was a comedy that wasn't funny. It was a suspense that wasn't suspenseful. It was a sci-fi that was neither cheesy enough to be comedic or creepy enough to give me the creeps.. That and, being gay, I was appalled at all the "let's laugh at the faggot!" jokes throughout. Done tastefully, I don't usually mind, but this wasn't done tastefully. I am not knocking the actors at all. They all performed up to the standard I had in my head for them, it was direction and scripting.

I was really looking forward to this movie. I'm sorry I spent $6.25 on it.

What a chance wasted is this movie! Did you read the book by Ira Levin? A very nice book. Unlike the movie, it leaves possibilities open: are the women robots or they just get used to "what an ordinary life means"? By the way, isn't this more terrifying in a way? It is very easy to explain everything very straightforwardly: this guy is a devil, shame on him! ... and now everything will be OK again, we know who's guilty.

I will tell you a story: man and wife move to town where everything seems to be just perfect. Everybody happy. But slowly they see that behind this happiness there is something strange: this happiness is just too perfect to be real. Real one is a bit sad, too, even if this sounds strangely. It isn't that "cool". The presented happiness is the one without ANY feeling, just the happiness like by produced by some machine. She didn't like this way of being happy, and of course she didn't. Who would? Well, maybe the man, since a PART of this happiness is that wives are sort of slaves to their husbands, which the men would like after all. But the women seem to be happy about this, too. And you may ask: is this OK or not? ... a lot of questions arises, you may try your own ones.

Slowly we are led to the point of the story: the woman becomes the same as the others. So what? Is there somebody who changes the wives into some strange kind of robots, whatever this means? Or she just merged into the society? Isn't this the problem of all of us, after all? Every of us probably told to him/herself once: I will NOT be like them (when I grow up, when I do the same job, when I move to this part of town...). But we did, probably? At this point the story ends. No explanation, you may say.

Are you interested in such kind of a story? Well, read the book, since nothing of it the movie offers. In the movie everything is clear: there is somebody changing the women into robots just to make men lazing their lives comfortably. The laboratory is shown, men has remote controls in their pockets. Even more, the reason is told: every one of these women has been once a successful director, manager, a.s.o. And... finally everything is explained plainly, and all the men meet in the shopping center forced to do the shopping.

Oh my god, how flat story has been made from a three dimensional book full of interesting questions!

Having read the Ira Levin book and seen the 1975 film, I was pleasantly surprised by the modern twist - emphasis on TWIST - of this "Stepford Wives" versus the original version. It kept the principal message of the story while almost spoofing it at the same time. As usual, Nicole Kidman was brilliant, and the already Stepford-ized actresses were eerily convincing enough to maintain the suspense. I hadn't expected to be kept guessing - or to be so entertained! Though I'm not sure it could be appreciated as a standalone film - as is evidenced by the many negative reviews it received - it definitely gave me the feeling of a tribute, almost as "High Society" was to "The Philadelphia Story." The comic timing of the ensemble even managed to make some clichés funny all over again.

review_title: If you accept the premise great, if not...run away
The Worst Movie I've Watched in a Long Time
review_detailed_main:
I must admit, I am not a fan of "campy" movies. My wife wanted to see this one, so we rented the DVD. Man, is it bad. The acting by Nicole Kidman was very much over the top. We all know she is capable of exceptional acting, so this had to be the direction. Matthew Broderick was so unaffected, that I thought his performance was going to cause narcolepsy.

The plot is simple-minded. The direction is awful. This tries to have a sci-fi twist to it, but they got that wrong as well. It is so far removed from anything close to reality, that the movie is more in the fairy tale genre than sci-fi. I can suspend disbelief, but there are limits. C'mon.

The deleted scenes on the DVD reveal that their was some notion of going way, way over the top with characters spontaneously developing long reaching mechanical arms and lawn-mowing attachments. This is in direct conflict of the premise that something is being done to these (human) women. It's good that they removed those scenes, but some of the remaining scenes suggest that these are robots, not humans. It's all a real mess.

This is total garbage and a total waste of my time.

The premise behind Stepford Wives presents enough substance for an intriguing film to be created. This is not that film.

It tries to be funny at first, but then attempts to switch into a deep-thinker movie towards the end leaving me staring at the screen going WTF. Rushed, flat, and head-scratchingly odd, Stepford Wives fails to achieve both of its goals of being funny and profound.

Verdict: Don't Watch.

I watched The Stepford Wives because of Bree Van De Camp in Desperate Housewives who I kinda like. However, the wives of Stepford are absolutely ridiculous. You don't even know those so-called perfect women are robots or human beings! At least, Bree is an emotional character, a human of flesh and blood. What's more, it seems to me that this film is a stigmatization of feminism.

Funny at first but then it got real sexist and offensive.. ya it's suppose to be comedy but I'm pretty sure most men wish they could have their wives just be sex bots and the low blow humor and slander against women and how the men talk about them.. yikes!

review_title: I loved this one, Glenn Close and Bette Midler ruled the show!
review_detailed_main:
I saw this one the day after it opened in Mt. Barker. I felt the audience was generally scared in the 'Kitchen Scene' with Bette Midler being robotized and being SCARY! The trailer is awesome and you'll here Nicole Kidman say "What have they done to you?!!" in your nightmares.

But they did have a major plot hole but forget about it, Glenn Close is simply adoring and has those cold robotic eyes as usual so the part was made for her. Bette Midler takes the cake as Bobbie ('I love you but please die!'). Matthew Boderick was severely out of place here, he was completely unlovable and you wanted to hate him for being in this film.

I don't like Nicole Kidman, never ever had, but she was good here and showed genuine sympathy and lose when her two best friends were taken from their lives.

A great film, i'll give it 9.5 (-.5 because of the plot hole). And i cannot wait to have this one on DVD!

Watched this on Netflix recently as I never got round to seeing it before. I was really surprised at how BAD it was. Really dated in light of the Me Too movement and recently more 'enlightened' attitudes to race and LGBT. Borderline offensive at times with those men sitting around and objectifying women. The Mathew Broderick character was awful and the way the story progresses makes you question Nicole's motives for staying with him. The 2 gay characters were stereotypes in every way imaginable. The Jewish character played by Bette who I usually love in anything was again awkwardly added in. She was very unfunny throughout and you got a sense she knew she was in a stinker. I love Nicole in everything but this was a bad mistake for her to lower herself to appear in. What was she thinking? Was there lots of money involved for all these A listers?This is one movie that should be quietly filed away somewhere...and forgotten....

It is a comedy indeed. I couldn't help but laugh at its absurdity and incompleteness. What 'The Stepford Wives' says is not only divisive to the sickness but also incoherent. How it tells that story is just the level of amateur. So many gaps and holes in the plot and so many scenes that do not make sense (logically even setting aside the sci-fi part of the movie) and do not connect.

What was Frank Oz thinking? He knows how to make good films. Dirty Rotten Scoundrels, anyone? So how did he misfire so horribly with this thing? Actually, I'm sure it wasn't all his fault for the outcome of this totally and utterly pointless remake of a decent film from yep, you guessed it, the 70's. Is it just me or is Hollywood having a midlife crisis? What's with all the needless remakes of already well-done flicks? What gives? Why can't they remake a crappy film and turn it into a true success story? Oh, because that would actually mean it has to be good...sorry, I forgot. With an excellent cast of tried and true actors you would naturally think they'd be able to bring the quality up past the mediocre script that was summoned for this ridiculous excuse of a film. Nicole Kidman, Matthew Broderick, Christopher Walken and Bette Midler would usually make for a pretty powerful cast. Here, however, they're all just flopping around in a nice-looking but astonishingly empty rehash of stuff we've already visited. Where's the novelty in that? It would be one thing if the creators attempted to take it into a different direction, thus giving validity to this remake. Alas, no such luck here. They just go through the motions and expect everyone to "ooh" and "aah" at a plot they think no one's ever heard of before at all. Who are they kidding? This is probably the most unfunny "black comedy" I've ever seen...And I use that term loosely, since there's really nothing "black" or "dark" about it at all; even though it wants you to believe that it indeed is...Don't fall for it. Do yourself a favor and just go watch the original 70's version which is much better than this thing could ever hope to be...It's lifeless, toothless and completely worthless...Don't waste your time...

This was much worse than I expected. The reality show parodies at the beginning fell flat, Bette Midler had no particularly funny lines, and the only laughs came from the tired queen stereotype gay men and some comically demented moments from Glenn Close. The 1975 film with Katharine Ross is no classic. Ross was such a passive movie presence in general that there was nothing at stake in the threat of her being transformed by the nefarious doings of the Stepford Men's Club. So the idea of a remake is a good one, especially since the backlash against feminism is still going strong even with the advances women have obtained in the last few decades - conservatives (male and female) are still criticizing working moms and some religious groups are more proactive in proselytizing about women subjecting their wills to their husbands. To give "Stepford Wives" the treatment it needs would require a dark satire, not the over-the-top dumb farce we get here. The performers do their best with the lousy material, though the idea that someone as young as Kidman would run a network struck me as implausible.

This movie I understand the concept. It made people look mean and hard to live with. I understand this with some people I lived with in the past. Life can be unpleasant. Nothing worse than coming home from a lousy job, and arriving at a worse home life. Selfishness, greed, and immaturity, is in my religion considered great sins, and creates great carnage. This movie hits the issue that God never made us robots, but gave us free will; the robots were not real people. No choice, like in 'A Clockwork Orange'. This would be a very dry relationship. I don't think that either the control freaks on both sides were happy people. I found acceptance in whatever my fate is, a better way; for my life has been one of misery, and I found control and illusion. One can just plan and do their best. The humor lacked on this heavy subject, and this movie got across as a TV movie. Christopher Walken is the only saving grace, as usual I give it a 5 out of 10.

If you want to see an entertaining movie then make it Stepford Wives. The cast is wonderful and plays the entire movie "tongue- in-cheek".I much prefer this version to the original. I'm sure this movie will never win Academy Awards but it does entertain!!!Glen Close and and Christopher Walken are hilarious and I must say that after viewing this film I have finally become a fan of Nicole Kidman. The costumes, by Ann Roth are beautiful and the setting are superb. Bette Midler is in top form and Roger Bart practically steals the show. One note: Even though Faith Hill is featured there actually is very little of her in the movie...she must have been a victim of the cutting room floor.

Unfortunately, I saw this version before I saw the Original 1975 version and I have to say that this version, for lack of a better word, totally sucks! The original 1975 version is at least 100 if not 1000 times better than this farce. The cutesy-poo whodunit ending make me want to vomit and every time I saw Matthew Broderick I was expecting him to yell out "Go-Go Gadget" because thats about the limit of his acting ability. So bad is this remake that I was actually shocked and taken aback at how different this is from the original. Even the controversy the original movie had over the womens lib movement back in the 70's is nothing compared to how horrible this movie is. This movie just goes to show that the American movie audience has lost its edge to distinguish what is good and what is bad in the filmed entertainment industry.The only thing I must strive for you to do if you see this abomination is to see the original and then compare the two. you will be shocked just as I was in how the quality of films have degraded over the years.

review_title: A deliciously campy mixture of satire and sci-fi.

review_detailed_main:
All that talent and all that hype and.....well this is one of my "thing" classifications. It just doesn't have anything in it that is good.

One wonders how so many talented people could spend (eight months I hear) on something this bad? The story is all basically told in the trailers that have shown for weeks, and the surprise ending or whatever you want to call it is about as exciting as a staring contest.

So rather than waste any more of your time...do yourself a favor...don't go see this and you will be a lot happier about it and you won't feel like I did post the "thing" that;.... I wanted my money back!

review_title: A Fun Version of The Stepford Wives but not a Laugh Out Riot

review_detailed_main:
I can imagine how "The Stepford Wives" could anger people, after seeing the original which I can only imagine to be the complete opposite of this (I haven't seen it) in the sense that it would be scary not funny. But if you just sit down and enjoy the film for what it is, it's actually a very watchable and amusing experience.

The person who makes the film is Bette Midler as the eccentric hippie writer. Once again she steals every scene with her funny lines and hilarious comedy timing. All fans of Bette Midler should definitely seek this out just for her alone! The film on the whole is actually quite witty and enjoyable it's just a shame the screenplay wasn't stronger on the story side!

"The Stepford Wives" could also be quite offensive to any gender or gay people. It's sexist in the way it portrays men as slobs sitting around in a circle playing robot wars and just treating women as objects, wanting nothing from them but sex and cash. Now I'm sure some men do (I hope the don't!) but for the majority of men I don't think that's what they want! It's also sexist in the way it portrays women as being good housewives, sitting around cleaning all day and making thousands of cupcakes. It's homophobic in the way it thrusts gay stereotypes onto us. Bear in mind that all of this is done through humour and shouldn't be taken seriously, but still some people could find this offensive!

Basically this is your standard chick-flick but with an added fizz, it's completely daft but fun. You can tell that everyone involved was having fun playing there part, Glenn Close was particularly enjoyable as the crazy owner of "Stepford". I quite enjoyed it, it certainly wasn't dull but is nothing out of the ordinary!

Okay. A lot of ground to cover. This film was expertly casted and crafted. It was shot well and had a good story line. The stupid thing with this movie is the continuity and genre. If they were going for comedy, they get an A, but the fact they were going for a "sci-fi thriller" makes me laugh out loud. The film is a good one. It makes you laugh. It turns ugly when they drop the comedy element and try to scare you in the last 30 minutes of the film. Also, with the continuity. They switch back and forth from saying the women are the original woman with microchips in their brains to saying they are robots. If there were only chips in their brains, why would the "robot" of Nicole Kidman be laying on the surface when it opens it's eyes. Doesn't anyone else find that strange? Seriously. Rewrite the ending and get a new story line. Stop remaking good films into garbage.

review_title: Promising at first, but collapsing after 45 minutes
review_detailed_main:
This remake offers a good cast, a promising team and first and foremost a very intriguing plot. Unfortunately the filmmakers could not entirely decide whether to make a sci fi thriller like the movie from the seventies or a comedy. It has a wonderful opening-credit sequence which hails the fifties with their nightmarish perfect-housewife-commercials and groundbreaking kitchen inventions. Then the movie sets his tone introducing Nicole Kidman as a superpopular TV-host (Mr. Kidman was never colder as a character)who bathes herself in the success of her cruel real-time TV shows. After getting fired for basically ruining peoples lives with inhumanly disgusting shows she finds herself in the superclean and somewhat unreal little town of Stepford. While Kidman's character is very well developed, her husband's is not. Matthew Broderick fails to persuade us that he is a true heartbreaker and a great companion for a career-woman such as Kidman. You don't believe that she actually fell in love with him, he is just to weak and boring.The couple just does not seem to belong together, the same problem we found in COLD MOUNTAIN with Kidman and Jude Law. Later we do not want to buy that Broderick's character is turned around by the macho-attitudes of the Stepford-husbands, he is too nice for that.

In the third act the whole thing collapses because the filmmakers do not succeed in turning this comedy into a really frightening thriller. This story is interesting because of the horrible truth being discovered at the end. Instead of leaving us with an open end which would make us moan the characters we fell in love with before (Kidman, Bette Midler) this movie delivers us a poor explanation that takes away the horror - and the horror is the most attractive part of this story in the first place. THE STEPFORD WIVES wants to be a comedy and a thriller, wants to be sarcastic, full of secrets, exiting, a little heart worming and shocking - and is nothing of the above completely. A straight thriller with this cast and crew would have made a great film. OK, I also had some laughs...only to bow my head during the last 15 minutes!

review_title: Better than a kick in the pants
review_detailed_main:
Silly fluff. Interesting new variations on the old classic. Some very dumb ideas...animated (poorly) robot dog, human cash machine.

A campy homage that is watchable just for Glenn Close and Christopher Walken. I have no trouble with Nicole Kidman's performance. It's true...Matthew Broderick seems really limited...and, not too cute anymore, either. I really like Jon Lovitz, but, he seemed miscast.

I won't get mad comparing this to the classic original. It's an homage, a fantasia. It has "camp" appeal. It was the only thing I could find on HBO that day.

It was far better than cleaning my kitchen, or, paying my bills !

My problems with this movie deal around the consistency and the pacing.

The movie starts of dreadfully slow. Slow and pointless. Then the movie speeds up. So far as to be in overdrive. Characters (mainly Joanne) have FAR too strong of reactions to simple situations. This gives a very piecemeal feeling to the entire movie.

By far my biggest complaint though is the lack of explanation and consistency when it comes to the actual wives. They call the wives robots, but they're not robots. They're normal woman with microchips implanted on their brains. Last time I checked that didn't resemble a robot in the slightest. But they had artificial bodies of the woman laying around... WHY!? So they're not robots, the movie tells us this... BUT they can burn themselves and not be hurt, have ELECTRICAL PROBLEMS, and DISPENSE CASH FROM THEIR MOUTHS. So how exactly does a microchip on the brain allow you to spit up money?

Frankly I'm baffled by this movie. I think they should recall the thing, fix the horribly obvious errors, and reship. Maybe then I would enjoy it more.

How do you go SO wrong, with such a good cast?

\/\/

The Stepford Wives is a movie that reeks of being in a hurry. Even though the filming schedule was elongated, the final product doesn't show it. The sets look as if they came under budget on time and effort. They look cheap and quickly thrown together. The change from Manhattan city life to perfect Stepford land is unnoticeable in the way the dress, setting and style of the film and characters appear. Because of this, it's clear that the clean and neat' style the film may have been going for is not a commentary on its theme of perfection, but simply the lack of effort to make it otherwise. The story is adapted from the original thriller, The Stepford Wives and hence the originality of its plot is not something the crew of this production can take credit for. Joanna Eberhart (Nicole Kidman) has lost her position has a high ranking official in the television world and, with her husband (Matthew Broderick) and their children, moves to Stepford, the setting of this mediocre thriller and `mystery'. Why are these women so perfect? Where do the men go all day? What do they do there? The audience knows the answers and so we watch Kidman try to answer these questions but instead simply establish herself as a drama queen. Her performance lacks originality and, although she is believable, she has not completely separated herself from Nicole into Joanna. The supporting cast is comic relief (and they're not really all that comical). Bett Middler plays the odd girl and with her gay sidekick, they join Joanna in an attempt to answer their questions about the robotic barbies posing as wives, but instead feel like extra baggage. Of course, it's just now that Joanna's there that the preoccupied feminist and her Queer Eye clone have decided that there's something strange going on. That's the movies for you. Or rather, that's Stepford. The cast and crew of this movie knew it was bad. They refused comment on it. They went back and attempted re-shoots to improve open it's flaws. But however it happened, a week of pick-up shots can't change the problem of this movie. In fact, the entire thing looks like it was filmed with ten different directors over the course of ten months. Every aspect of each scene looks like it was stolen from twenty different movies and then photoshopped to fit the current directors image. This movie is clumsy, confused and very un-Stepford. **/*****

"The Stepford Wives" is an adolescent stab at a comical film. There are some saving moments, however, they are few a far between. And the attempt to be funny is so obvious that one remains feeling sorry for the quality actors involved. Glen Close is tragically misused. Christopher Walkin is stiff and uncomfortable in his comic role, although in a way he plays a villain. The computer generated gimmicks are odd. Bette Mitler is funny in her role, but the film is not worth her performance. Nicole Kidman is misused, particularly in view of all of her great work in the past. This film should remain asleep in the can. Don't waste your time with it. Perhaps renting it in the months to come will be o.k. if you have nothing better to do.

review_title: Some Spoilers, beware! And, it's a tad confusing!
A parody of 1950s American housewives with a secret
For the most part not as good as the original

review_detailed_main: If you look at it as a surreal comedy, you might actually laugh a few times.
Love this remake (not something often said). Bright and funny with a much better ending. Kidman so good (per usual), but Bette and Roger Bart as her buddies and the whole cast are just terrific.

review_title: love is to accept just the way she is
review_detailed_main:
it is very funny. I like it so much. I like it when suddenly bette middler change her behaviors.

I like the last scene, where Nicole Kidman gracefully walk and fool everyone. The story is quiet funny although not perfect. The homo couple is the most irritating. I don't understand why they are in the film. The idea of changing your woman's mind and body with electronic device and then control her with remote control is funny. Where you can also inflate your woman's breast with remote. :-D Where every couple have sex in the daylight. I still wondering if the husband did go to work. When?

First, Kidman, a poor actress, is perfect in this ridiculous and annoying movie.

Yes, poor. An anonymous reviewer put it better than I could: Through most of her film roles, Nicole Kidman more or less comes off as the tall poppy with whispery voice and an ice queen propensity. If not that, she tries too hard to come across as a serious actress and unfortunately, falls short when it comes to her range of expression capability.

That aside; this flick is disjointed. The best part is the climax (as you might expect); where we find out Glenn Close is even more insane than the Stepford husbands; who willingly have their wives sacrificed in favor of obedient, physically hot Robotesses who scream in bed each time their vaginal micro-switches are tripped. Really? The only ones that would go for this, are guys that already own blow up dolls, and I would surmise that's a very small percentage of the population.

And the opening scene is just plain dumb & insulting It comes off as a poor play.

The original was fairly creepy (and unfortunately poorly directed as it moved much too slowly the 1st hour or so), otherwise it had great potential. This 2004 remake; is well...... I guess 'Hokey' & as I said, annoying would be apt terms. And the original had the gorgeous and lively Paula Prentiss. What a doll she is in that.

I'm still trying to determine if this remake was worth the time of one viewing. Its attempt at works a couple times, but that's it. And the movie doesn't know what genre it wants to be.

Still, with Midler, Close, Ferris Bueller, and a wacky Chris Walken, I guess I'd have to lean for recommending watching it once; you know; if your in a leg cast and you misplaced your walker and remote.

I'll say this, my wife got semi-hooked on it (according to her); "just to see where the heck it was going". But she said it basically stunk overall.

Sorry, I realize this is not a very objective review this time. I'm hoping my subjective comments point you in the right direction though.

For me, I found the acting and directing, repeatedly annoying. I've never seen that before and I hope I don't see it again.

Thx. Bob R.

Several things really bothered me about this movie, but the biggest was that there was no real suspense created. The movie gave away pretty much all it's secrets right away. I was unfamiliar with what it was going to be about and found it highly disappointing. Even when I see movies I know the end to I expect more suspense than this offers.

I thought all of the actors turned in brilliant performances; Nicole Kidman was emotionally driven, and all the other actors seemed to really do a nice job, including the Wives, who had to act perfect in unison. Even the oft-criticized Matthew Broderick made a good mediocre husband to his powerhouse wife, and I could see him wrestling with his decision, but it created very little drive for the story.

I think the bulk of this movie's problem seemed to be how it was all put together. It could have explored a lot of issues deeper, it could have been a lot more engaging, but it wasn't. The film couldn't make up it's mind what it wanted to be, and wound up being nothing.

Plus there was the robot/microchip inconsistency...

review_title: Make your freaking minds up! (MAJOR SPOILERS)

review_detailed_main: Greetings again from the darkness. Director Frank Oz is best known for playing Yoda in the Star Wars movies, voice work on the Muppets his comedy films such as "What About Bob?" , "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels" and his best work, "Bowfinger". I am embarrassed for him after seeing his remake of "The Stepford Wives". Not sure if this should be called a remake since its predecessor by 29 years was a much darker, more serious film than the current fluff. This script is awful and the casting is equally atrocious. Matthew Broderick is no actor. He peaked at "War Games" and should just sit back and spend his husband money from "Sex and the City". I fully understand Nicole Kidman wanting to take a walk on the lighter side after her last 3 or 4 years, but even Kidman can't make this one work. Glenn Close steals most of her scenes as the smiling twin sister to her Cruella Deville role from the Dalmation movies, but even her role falls apart at the end. Christopher Walken is good for a couple of laughs, but overall this is a real stinker. Bette Midler does little but pose in a frumpy manner a couple of times. I did like the premise with the twist on the previous lives of the husband and wives, but of course, it was not developed properly. Terribly disappointing, so skip it if you are looking for a comedy, or pick up the original if you want a darker drama.

review_title: They don't make movies like this anymore
review_detailed_main: This is brilliant. This is movie from past times where you know it will be good based on facts it is starring Nicole Kidman. I didn't watch original and I don't plan to. I am visual creature and I don't like dated stuff.

I once saw this movie, way back when it was first released. Time hasnt been kind to this movie, which it's biggest problem is that it simply aint funny.

Not any good? Great actors, lots of terrific actors are starring in it, but nonetheless this movie tanked.
The Stepford Wives (1975) was very bad , but this one is even worse !

review_title: Don't Forget to Add Value to Your Remake
review_detailed_main:
It's hard to review films which are re-makes or re-hashes of an original. But lets try! We all know the basic conceit of the film in that husbands can replace their over-achieving wives with eponymous housewives - who are for decorative value with their 'drive' in business/science/political life etc removed and replaced with a subservient decorative 'housewife' aspect.

I find 'successful America' a shallow backdrop, but this is necessary here as the plot involves the well to do in their gated estate. The general situation emerges in an unsubtle way. Wives are shallow and ornamental, and time is spent allowing the husbands to confirm that is how they want their wives to be.

We know there is something peculiar going on when one of the wives has a malfunction during a civic dance. This pretty much confirms Kidmans sense that something is amiss. Walken makes an an appearance as the brains behind the situation, but without any suspense or intrigue about his character or what that character does. There is a housewife who doesn't appear to fulfil the ideal presented played by Midler. But the role played is simply to provide the contrast between actual wives and the 'ideal' wives. She ends up being converted, but to be honest, I was wondering why she had not been up to that point.

There is a decision to be taken by Broderick in respect of his wife, but watch the film to see what this is. The final part of the film comes at a ballroom event, and we are then told what we need to know about the wives, who is responsible and the status of the relationship between Kidman/Broderick.

There is a pretty poor twist to the film's ending, but it adds little.

A film which seemed more about the American high-life than the basic scenario about re-manufacturing individuals as life-style accessories and dealing with issues that might be expected to arise.

The film was visually attractive, but lacking in any real plot development and ultimately for the characters, a lack of empathy or understanding.

review_title: Could've used a lot more spark and subtlety
refreshing comedy with charm and heart
review_detailed_main: Having read the comments on IMDb and the quite average votes this movie has got, I was sceptical and I didn't know whether I would like it or not. So I ignored Stepford Wives at the box office. Today, I saw it as a bargain at my local grocery store, bought it, went home, put it into my DVD-player and... I was surprised. I still am. The Stepford wives is really a movie worth watching and I must say, I really (!!!) like it. If you like comedies with heart, charm, a touch of romance and also some things to think about, then this is definitely one for you. All actors are at least doing good jobs, some are splendid and the story itself is really lovable. Yes, the plot has some tiny weaknesses, but nothing to really bother about. Watch it and judge by yourself. The story itself is witty, smartly designed and it will catch you in a way that you will lose your interest in looking for some minor flaws. I give this movie 8 out of ten and it really deserves this vote. Try it!

review_title: not worth your time to see
review_detailed_main:
This movie tried to mix multiple genres and just didn't work. It was very boring in between the funny scenes. Me sitting in the movie theater just wanted to take a remote and hit "fast forward". The movie had a lot of nauseating all happy scenes, that didn't contribute anything to the plot. I feel they were inserted just to eat up time. I feel this whole movie can easily be edited into a 1 hr primetime TV episode.

Also there were many conflicting things that just didn't make sense. Making you feel there are different scripts and plots that were edited together, I cant even say combined. Most of little scenes aren't linked to each other.

Also I could predict the entire movie from just the TV trailers. There really isn't anything to see, its just like waiting for the end, no climax. Plus I feel like I wasted my time in the theater, if this was HBO I would have turned off the TV after 5-10 minutes. Only reason I sat it out was because I paid $10 to see and I wanted to get something.

This movie was a good idea, but just is too unorganized. It would have made a very nice horror/thriller movie/crime drama/horror sci-fi. But instead it tried to be funny, but not in a SNL or scary movie style funniness or a parody. This mixed genre just made the movie nauseating. There is subtle humor, but it just isn't mixed in very nicely (mostly Nicole does it).

In my opinion, if u need a movie that u can, um, be affectionate to your partner in. Stepford Wives is perfect, its so boring and not really interesting u can um take care of your partner.

Trying to remake this story as a comedy was obviously a stupid idea. Creating a remake to be significantly different from the original is one thing; to change the genre completely doesn't work.

Nicole Kidman has acted very well in many roles - but she's awful in this.

I saw this movie for my birthday when it came out in June. The first time I saw it I saw it, I enjoyed enormously. The second time, the critic in me reared its ugly head and I started noticing all the not-so-good parts. And the bad does seem to outweigh the good. But, if you're in need of some mindless fun and stargazing, this is the right movie. The cast does a wonderful job with what they have, turning what could have been some horrid, mind-numbing garbage into humorous, exceptionally cheesy fun. Nicole Kidman does a bang up job in this less than stellar role, as does Matthew Broderick and Christopher Walken. But the movie was stolen by the supporting cast of Bette Midler as the outspoken wonderfully blunt Bobbie Markowitz, Glenn Close as the psychotically perfect Claire and of course where would we be without the dumb blonde? Faith Hill does a hilarious job as the seemingly brainless Sarah Sunderson. If you happen to find this movie, do not expect a chillingly dark horror, but rather a fairly corny comedy that still leaves you wondering.

review_title: It could have been so much better
review_detailed_main:
I haven't seen the original 1975 version, so I can't say whether this version is much better or worse than the original one. What I do know is that the idea behind the movie isn't very original, but can, without being great, still become something nice,...

But it didn't. Of course it is funny to see how the men all want to change their bossy, career driven wives into loving, caring spouses, but it is oh so predictable. The women are all really unpleasant people (to put it in a very nice way), the men are their little slaves... When the families of two of these women move to a little town where they see that all the man can do what they want, don't have to bother about what the women think and clearly are the boss at home, the husbands want to change their wives as well.

Than of course you get the obvious scenes which belong to this kind of movies. It is so predictable that you wonder why you even paid money to watch it. It seems that you wrote the script yourself ... when having a bad hangover from the weekend before. In my opinion, this movie really shouldn't have been made. I give it a score of 4,5/10. I sure hope the original was a lot better!

After all the stories I'd heard, I was a bit skeptical, but the preview audiences I watched it with ate it up. It was funny and light and looked attractive, and Nicole Kidman keeps showing that she owns the big screen. As for the ending, I liked it but was surprised and wonder whether they'll keep it. It's good to see the terrific Glenn Close on the big screen again as well, though I've never really liked Midler. Christopher Walken was appropriately chilling (he can do that so well), and the audience LOVED Nicole's gay friend. Faith Hill fans will be somewhat disappointed, however, that she does not have a very big part, but she looks great in what she does have.

Sleazy TV executive Nicole Kidman (as Joanna Eberhart) survives after a disgruntled reality show star tries to assassinate her - but, Ms. Kidman suffers a nervous breakdown, after being fired by shareholders. Sensitive husband Matthew Broderick (as Walter Kresby) decides to quit his lesser-paying job, and use the couple's obviously substantial savings to buy an early retirement home in the "perfect" town of Stepford, Connecticut. Ladylike realtor Glenn Close (as Claire Wellington) explains, "It has no crime, no poverty, and no pushing." Strangest of all, most of "The Stepford Wives" obey their husbands with robotic subservience. They are ultra-perfect housewives - cleaning, cooking, and always ready for sex.

Quickly, Kidman comes back to her senses, and becomes friendly with singularly untidy resident Bette Midler (as Bobbie Markowitz) and girlishly gay Roger Bart (as Roger Bannister). Meanwhile, Mr. Broderick joins the men's club fronted by Ms. Close's husband, the well-coiffed Christopher Walken (as Mike Wellington). When her imperfect pals begin to change, Kidman thinks something's rotten in Stepford. And, she's right. Watching it unfold is moderately enjoyable, but there are missteps and missed opportunities. Kidman, to her credit, tries to turns it around; but, the opening makes you dislike the lead character. Also, however it was in the original book or earlier film - here, the last act badly needs revision.

**** The Stepford Wives (6/6/04) Frank Oz ~ Nicole Kidman, Matthew Broderick, Glenn Close, Bette Midler

Usually I have no problems with remakes if they're done successfully. Of course, that didn't authorize Gus Van Sant's Psycho, but that's beside the point. Frank Oz (who many recognize as the voice of Yoda and Miss Piggy from the Muppets, among others), already had one successful remake under his belt (the enjoyable Little Shop of Horrors), but needed more. So he decided to remake an obscure 1975 thriller about a town that's too perfect, The Stepford Wives. And now I think I'm on the bandwagon on saying that all of these remakes need to be stopped NOW.

Joanna (Nicole Kidman, badly masking her accent yet again) is a successful TV person (executive? president? I don't remember), but after there's an assassination attempt on her (during a 15 minute overview of the new season-completely unnecessary [except for a 'pun' later]), she's fired. She and her less successful husband Walter (Matthew Broderick, who seems to be underused lately) move with their two kids to Stepford, Connecticut, where it seems like everyone's stuck in the 1950's. But something's not right, as Joanna senses, and tries to discover what it is, while Walter gets dragged into the chauvinistic society that the Stepford husbands share. Random characters (including that ubiquitous Christopher Walken) ensue.

I could reiterate what every reviewer has been saying. I could say how this attempt at comedy, drama, and horror tries to be all three and fails at all three-which it does, completely. It falls over on its padded-runtime face many times whenever it tries to be one of the three. When it tries to be funny, it just isn't: you can flush the toilets from a control panel by the front door. Now isn't that hilarious? And when Walter has to choose between Joanna and a "perfect" wife (you'll understand if you see the movie...but you really shouldn't see it), the drama's supposed to be running high up. DUH! What do you think's gonna happen? And the whole concept (which might have been scary in the 1975 version, I didn't see it) just isn't scary. All of these problems don't lie in Oz (it seems like he's doing a bit of struggling for work), but in Paul Rudnick's screenplay. He tries to squeeze so much into it that it just doesn't work. Any of the plot "twists" that come about can be seen basically during the opening credits. Well, not the "final" twist, but that's too stupid to even mention.

Characters run to and fro without an iota of development (Jon Lovitz was in the movie?) and pop in just to say "funny" things or to help the "plot" along. But that's not even the worst of it. In every single scene-no exaggeration-there is either a boom mike or part of the camera in frame. I can forgive one or two-those things are pretty hard to avoid-but Stepford is such a slipshod, one-hand-tied-behind-your-back movie that they just don't care about making something that's technically well done. The only thing well done about this movie is Roger Bart as one of Stepford's only two gay men (such a stretch from his role as Carmen Ghia in the Broadway version of The Producers). Without his small character, the movie would be laugh less, every character uninteresting, and, well, the movie would still be awful. Basically, stay away from The Stepford Wives.

My rating: 3/10

After watching "The Stepford Wives" I can't help but feel cheated. I wasn't exactly expecting a movie that would be filled with non-stop laughs, but I was expecting at least a chuckle or two.

The movie stars Nicole Kidman as a TV executive who is unceremoniously terminated after a reality based show she produced resulted in a jaded husband going psycho and shooting up his estranged wife and her lovers (oh please). To brighten her perspective on life after show biz, her husband (Matthew Broderick) moves her and their children to a small town named Stepford in Connecticut. Here everything seems to be perfect. The wives are the epitome of happiness; smiles, cheerfulness and a spunk not seen since the late 1950s. On the other hand, the husbands seem to do nothing but play with rock 'em sock 'em robots, smoke cigars, and generally be chauvinistic. Kidman's character slowly begins to discover clues to point to something dark going on behind closed doors in Stepford that causes the women change their personalities.

I have not yet seen the original, but I have heard much about it and it appears that it was a thriller/horror flick. That sounds like the way to go with this material. Oz's version leans heavily in the direction of camp, and the one-liners start to pile up like driftwood.

The characters react in totally illogical ways; no one seems to be at all fazed or even mildly surprised about the sinister goings-on in Stepford. Furthermore, there is absolutely NO chemistry between Kidman and Broderick on-screen. The few scenes that do attempt to convey emotion are static and stale and incredibly awkward. It seems to me that a trained chimp could have done Broderick's job in this film, which seemed to consist of complaining half-heartedly and looking slightly confused. And don't even get me started on Christopher Walken. The man has played some incredible roles and he is as intense an actor as you will ever find, but in this film it seemed as though he were playing a bad parody of one of his Saturday Night Live roles.

As if this already weren't enough, we are treated to a jangly edit, where it seems that everything is rushed along just a bit too quickly, and it looks as though vital scenes were just clipped right out of the movie. A solid, slow development of characters and mood is trashed in favor of more unfunny one-liners. Furthermore, Oz changes direction on us mid-movie and attempts to create a creepy sci-fi thriller vibe, but it falls flat after all that camp shoved down our throats in the first 50 minutes.

As a testament to how bad this movie sucked, the best aspect of the whole film was the outrageously stereotypical flamboyantly gay Stepford 'wife.' He was the only funny thing in the entire movie. That is just plain sad.
